story:
This campaign is to collect pre orders for an unofficial Raspberry Pi computer case or “PiBox” that can be made and shipped a few weeks after the campaign closes. The funds will cover the cost of making a mold, getting the parts made, and shipped to you.

What We Need & What You Get

  • I’ll need to have $14,500 to have about 600 plastic cases made so that people can have a home for their Raspberry Pi.
  • Perks
    • The PiBox can be made and shipped for $25 so I’ll sell it to you for $25. If you want more make sure to pay in multiples of 25.
    • If you’d like to just register your interest donate a dollar. If we get enough people the costs will come down.
  • If you really want to help make this happed a donation of $300 will get you a custom made aluminum case just to say thanks.
  • This is a fixed funded project so if we don’t get enough pre-orders your money goes right back to you, no risk.
  • If the project isn't funded no mold or parts will be made.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, I understand, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help!

Share this everywhere you can, friends, family, your coworkers!

Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Comment in the raspberrypi.org forums, there are some really neat people there!

Comment on the campaign let me know what you think or ask questions, check back often!

Who am I?

I'm Rob Erickson, in January I first learned about the Raspberry Pi computer from a friend and haven't been able to stop thinking about it. I’ve been excited at the new possibilities that such a small and inexpensive computer can provide to the world. Then I learned about the goal of the Raspberry Pi Foundation and its goal to use it as a classroom aid to teach children and that made me admire all that hard work that has gone into making it. I wanted to find a way to be a part of that same excitement.

My specialty is mechanical engineering and hardware packaging so I was naturally wondered how the Raspberry Pi computer was going to be encased. All I could find was that there was a promise of a case latter on. So on my day off I modeled a few designs and had so much fun I couldn’t stop, after a while I wanted to see what my case really looked like. Searching the internet all I found were methods that gave less than desirable quality or the cost was too high.

That’s when it hit me, “Why not injection mold it and have a good quality part?” I’ve seen a few crowd funded products be a successful and I didn’t see any reason why it would be impossible. The demand for the Raspberry Pi is so huge that even if I had less than 1% of the people who are interested in it buy a case that would more than pay for the initial cost.

 

 

Thanks!
story_txt:
This campaign is to collect pre orders for an unofficial Raspberry Pi computer case or “PiBox” that can be made and shipped a few weeks after the campaign closes. The funds will cover the cost of making a mold, getting the parts made, and shipped to you.
What We Need & What You Get

I’ll need to have $14,500 to have about 600 plastic cases made so that people can have a home for their Raspberry Pi.
Perks

The PiBox can be made and shipped for $25 so I’ll sell it to you for $25. If you want more make sure to pay in multiples of 25.
If you’d like to just register your interest donate a dollar. If we get enough people the costs will come down.

If you really want to help make this happed a donation of $300 will get you a custom made aluminum case just to say thanks.
This is a fixed funded project so if we don’t get enough pre-orders your money goes right back to you, no risk.
If the project isn't funded no mold or parts will be made.
Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can’t contribute, I understand, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help!
Share this everywhere you can, friends, family, your coworkers!
Use the Indiegogo share tools!
Comment in the raspberrypi.org forums, there are some really neat people there!
Comment on the campaign let me know what you think or ask questions, check back often!
Who am I?
I'm Rob Erickson, in January I first learned about the Raspberry Pi computer from a friend and haven't been able to stop thinking about it. I’ve been excited at the new possibilities that such a small and inexpensive computer can provide to the world. Then I learned about the goal of the Raspberry Pi Foundation and its goal to use it as a classroom aid to teach children and that made me admire all that hard work that has gone into making it. I wanted to find a way to be a part of that same excitement.
My specialty is mechanical engineering and hardware packaging so I was naturally wondered how the Raspberry Pi computer was going to be encased. All I could find was that there was a promise of a case latter on. So on my day off I modeled a few designs and had so much fun I couldn’t stop, after a while I wanted to see what my case really looked like. Searching the internet all I found were methods that gave less than desirable quality or the cost was too high.
That’s when it hit me, “Why not injection mold it and have a good quality part?” I’ve seen a few crowd funded products be a successful and I didn’t see any reason why it would be impossible. The demand for the Raspberry Pi is so huge that even if I had less than 1% of the people who are interested in it buy a case that would more than pay for the initial cost.
 
 
Thanks!
